history.content: These are all good suggestions.  The limiting factor for summer offerings is qualified instructors and then the size of upper division courses is limited by the supply of qualified (U)GSIS.  Faculty focus on research -- as well as vacations -- during the summer and so it usually means finding graduate students who are qualified to be lead instructors for summer session courses.  Undergrad TAs are easier to find for summer courses for lower division courses but by the time they are ready to TA for upper div courses, many undergrads prioritize internships and other opportunities during summer session. Still, we will keep trying.

children.subject:
Gotta recognize that increased opportunity cost and increase pay/perks for upper div TAs then!

Haha yes, we recognize you guys do a lot of work and appreciate the effort. Thanks, and rest easy, knowing that your efforts, if they do come through, truly help hundreds and even thousands of students!

history.content:
Given how impacted some CS upper divs have been this semester and possibly next semester for a variety of factors (including Wheeler renovstions) is there any way to request that the CS department start thinking now-ish about the potential to offer more summer CS classes next summer. This summer had 188 but I know others (162? 170?) have been taught over the summer as well, previously, and it would certainly be helpful for 200-500 people (a significant number) per summer to offer these classes. 

The policy of also grabbing visiting faculty for teaching MORE upper divs (like 186 this semester) could also help with spreading the impact of huge enrollments around.

Just some suggestions for you guys to think about. I know.its been a frustrating summer for quite a few people with SIS and heavy CS enrollment.
history.subject: CS Summer Classes
